An Old Man, whose life had been a testament to tireless labor and frugal living, resided in a verdant village by the banks of a meandering river. As the silver threads of age multiplied in his hair and his body grew weary, he decided, in an act of profound trust, to distribute his entire fortune—his fertile lands, a chest of glistening silver rupees, and a handful of precious family jewels—among his two strapping young men, his sons. He believed this would ensure their prosperity and his own peaceful twilight years under their care. However, no sooner had the wealth been divided and registered in their names, than the wretched, selfish ingrates cast off their filial pretense. They relegated their Father to a cramped, dusty corner of the cattle shed, offered him only the coarsest grains and water, and met his gentle pleas with scornful glares and harsh words, leaving the poor Old Man to suffer indignity and hunger. 

Summary:
An elderly man, after distributing his wealth to his selfish sons, is cruelly abandoned, only for his loyal friend Gopal to trick them into showing false devotion by presenting fake gold bags. The sons, driven by greed, lavish attention on their father until his death, only to discover the "treasures" are worthless river stones, revealing their own foolishness and the futility of their avarice.
